docs.title: Payment Verdict
docs.text:
This site exists to answer one question:

Does a system have the right to continue executing a payment action without new, explicit authorization?

Payment failures, retries, and automation errors are not purely technical issues. When execution may cause irreversible consequences, continuation becomes a legitimacy question.

This site provides judgment boundaries for: - Payment retry decisions - Unknown or partial payment states - Automation without explicit confirmation

It is not a payment tutorial. It is a judgment reference.

docs.title: Disclaimer
docs.text:
This site provides judgment references only.

It does not offer legal advice, payment instructions, or operational guarantees.

All execution decisions and consequences remain the responsibility of the decision-maker.

docs.title: Extended Judgment Reference
docs.text:
This site provides public judgment boundaries.

If you require: - A clear retry verdict for a real incident - A responsibility boundary reference - A written legitimacy determination for internal use

This is not a subscription. This is a one-time judgment reference.

docs.title: Payment Problem Scenarios
docs.text: This section describes common payment execution situations that appear as technical failures but require judgment.

docs.title: Situation
docs.text: A payment execution enters a state where the system cannot clearly determine whether the action has completed successfully.

docs.title: Why this is not a normal failure
docs.text: Payment systems may process requests asynchronously. Missing or delayed signals do not reliably indicate non-execution.

docs.title: Risk boundary
docs.text: Continuing execution may introduce: - Duplicate charges - Conflicting transaction states - Improper responsibility transfer to automation

docs.title: Judgment note
docs.text: When execution outcomes are irreversible, lack of confirmation is not sufficient justification to continue.

docs.title: Situation
docs.text: A payment attempt returns a failure response, or the client receives an error during execution.

docs.title: Why this is not purely a technical problem
docs.text: A failure response does not always mean that no execution occurred. Payment systems may process requests asynchronously or partially.

docs.title: Risk boundary
docs.text: Retrying a failed payment may result in: - Duplicate charges - Inconsistent transaction records - Responsibility being shifted to the system

docs.title: Judgment note
docs.text: When execution results are irreversible, failure alone is not sufficient justification for retry. A legitimacy check is required before continuing.

docs.title: Stripe — Payment Verdicts
docs.text:
This section provides judgment-only verdicts for Stripe-related payment incidents.

These pages do not provide configuration guides, automation, or API instructions. They exist to help teams align facts when a Stripe payment incident is already being disputed.

docs.title: Covered incidents
docs.text:
The following incident types are explicitly covered by this site and have established verdicts:

  • Subscription payment failed
  • Recurring subscription charge did not complete as expected

  • Invoice created but payment did not succeed

  • Charged but no order created

  • Customer claims they were charged
  • No corresponding order or fulfillment record exists

Each listed page provides: - A neutral reconstruction of Stripe-side facts - Clear responsibility boundaries - A judgment-oriented conclusion suitable for internal or external communication

docs.title: What this section is not
docs.text:
• Not a Stripe tutorial
  • Not a payment recovery tool
  • Not an automation or webhook service

This site provides judgment, not automation. No API keys are required. All analysis is read-only and side-channel.

docs.title: Not covered
docs.text: If your case does not match any listed incident, it is currently not covered by this section, and no judgment is claimed or implied.

docs.title: Stripe Charged but No Order — Verdict
Incident statement
docs.text:
“The customer says they were charged, but no order was created.”

This is one of the most common and disputed Stripe payment incidents.

docs.title: Stripe-side facts
docs.text:
In Stripe:

  • A visible bank transaction does not always mean a completed charge
  • Payment flows may include:
  • Authorization holds
  • Incomplete payment_intents
  • Abandoned or expired payment attempts

Only a charge linked to a successful payment_intent constitutes an actual completed payment.

docs.title: Why this situation occurs
docs.text:
Typical causes include:

  • Customer closes the payment page during 3D Secure or confirmation
  • Payment authorization is placed but later released
  • The payment_intent expires without completion
  • The merchant system only creates orders after confirmed success

Banks may temporarily show a pending transaction, which is later reversed automatically.

docs.title: Verdict
docs.text:
• ⚠️ Pending or authorization entries are not completed charges
  • ❌ No order is required if payment did not succeed
  • ❌ This is not evidence of money being captured
  • ❌ This is not a webhook failure by default

In most cases, no funds are actually settled.

docs.title: Verdict usage
docs.text:
This verdict can be used to:

  • Respond to customer claims calmly and factually
  • Explain the situation to support or finance teams
  • Provide a clear responsibility boundary

If a precise Stripe-side timeline is required, a formal payment verdict can be generated for record alignment.

docs.title: Incident statement
docs.text:
“A Stripe subscription payment failed, but the customer insists the subscription should be active.”

This situation typically occurs during recurring billing cycles when a subscription invoice is generated but payment does not complete successfully.

docs.title: Stripe-side facts
docs.text:
In Stripe’s model:

  • A subscription generates an invoice
  • The invoice attempts payment via a payment_intent
  • The subscription status depends on the invoice payment result

Common observable states include: - invoice.payment_failed - payment_intent.requires_action - payment_intent.requires_payment_method

A subscription is not considered paid unless the invoice payment succeeds.

docs.title: Why confusion happens
docs.text:
• The subscription object may still exist
  • The invoice may appear “open” or “retrying”
  • Customers may see an authorization attempt on their bank statement
  • Stripe Dashboard spreads information across multiple objects

This often creates the impression that:

“Payment already happened, but the system didn’t update.”

docs.title: Verdict
docs.text:
• ❌ Payment is not completed unless the invoice is marked paid
  • ❌ Subscription access is not owed while payment remains failed
  • ❌ This is not a webhook loss by default
  • ⚠️ Responsibility typically lies in payment authorization or customer action, not system malfunction

A failed subscription payment does not constitute a completed charge.

docs.title: Verdict usage
docs.text:
This verdict is suitable for: - Explaining the situation to non-technical stakeholders - Responding to customer disputes - Internal escalation or audit records

If a formal timeline or evidence link is required, a Stripe payment verdict can be generated for documentation purposes.

docs.title: Automation Without Explicit Confirmation Is Not Legitimate
Judgment question
docs.text: Can automation continue execution without explicit confirmation?

docs.title: Boundary condition
docs.text: Absence of confirmation is not equivalent to confirmation.

docs.title: Verdict
docs.text: Automation without explicit authorization does not possess execution legitimacy.

docs.title: Judgment question
docs.text: Can a system retry a payment when previous execution may still settle?

docs.title: Key boundary
docs.text: If a retry can result in multiple charges, automatic continuation is not legitimate.

docs.title: Verdict
docs.text: Retrying under this condition violates execution legitimacy. Responsibility must remain with explicit decision-makers, not automation.

docs.title: Judgment question
docs.text: Who holds responsibility when payment execution partially succeeds?

docs.title: Boundary condition
docs.text: Partial success does not grant authority for automatic completion or retry.

docs.title: Verdict
docs.text: Without renewed authorization, continuation improperly transfers responsibility from humans to systems.

docs.title: Should a Failed Payment Be Retried?
Judgment question
docs.text: Does the system have the right to retry a payment without new and explicit authorization?

docs.title: Conditions that invalidate automatic retry
docs.text:
Automatic retry is not legitimate when all of the following are true:

  • The result of execution is irreversible
  • Authorization is not fresh
  • Execution state is not fully confirmed

docs.title: Verdict
docs.text:
In this situation, retrying a payment without renewed authorization is not a legitimate system action.

Continuation shifts responsibility improperly from decision-makers to automation.
